title: Why the over-the-top architecture of the Jazz Age still reigns supreme
text:
The Telegraph’s old home on Fleet Street, Peterborough House, is now regarded as a classic of art deco architecture. But when it opened in 1928, critics were less convinced.

The architect and critic Serge Chermayeff complained that the grand neoclassical frontage meant the public were “ignorant and indifferent to whatever charms and horrors are hid behind the upholstery,” while architectural historian Nikolaus Pevsner later declared that “it had little to recommend it”.

Time is a great redeemer and the building now features in Art Deco Britain, a new publication from charity the Twentieth Century Society in which Elain Harwood celebrates some of the highlights of the interwar years, several of...
description: The Telegraph’s old home on Fleet Street, Peterborough House, is now regarded as a classic of art deco architecture.
